digital-services.data-consistency-checkbox-text: I want to enable data consistency
digital-services.data-consistency-description: Data consistency indicates where the evaluation was unable to produce indicators. This does not mean that there is no impact, but only that part of the impact could not be assessed. The causes of inconsistency are mainly missing data in the repository. For example, for BoaviztAPI, the impact factors for the distribution and end-of-life phases are not available.

version.ds-text: Want to build a digital service that’s both useful and responsible? Start by adding your resources and calculating the environmental impact of your project. It’s your chance to design a leaner, more transparent, and planet-friendly solution.
version.ds-name-placeholder: Type the name of your digital service here
version.ds-version-text:
You will be able to create and edit many versions of your Digital Service.
Each version captures a specific state, allowing you to track your progress, test different hypotheses and compare their effects without affecting the active version. Once you’re satisfied with a version, you can make it your active one, the previous active version will be automatically archived.

welcome-page.title: Welcome Page
welcome-page.name: Home
welcome-page.about-g4it: G4IT is designed to help to implement a sustainable digital approach for your information systems and digital services.
welcome-page.getting-started-text: When you first log in, a demo workspace is available to you. You can switch between workspaces at any time via the menu in the top right corner of the application (the name of the current workspace is displayed). You also have the option to create a new workspace within your {{ organizationName }} organization to conduct your own assessments and invite other users to join you.

digital-service.description: Calculate the impact of a digital service involves three levels: the end-user terminals, the volume of data passing through the network, and the hosting infrastructures.

eco-mind-ai.title: EcoMind AI
eco-mind-ai.description: Calculate the impact of a service integrating an AI algorithm, guide early choices to reduce it through best practices, and ensure its monitoring throughout the project.

global.info-fis-title: What is the meaning of people eq. ?
global.info-fis-text: If every human being respected planetary limits, each of us would have an individual package that would guarantee the sustainable balance of the system: The people equivalent (Eq. People) concept represent the number of people respecting this sustainable individual package. It was performed by dividing planet boundary from each criteria (ref. JRC Technical report - Consumption and Consumer Footprint: methodology and results) by the number of people on Earth.

tooltip.elec-consumption: Total power consumption of my organization's equipment for one year (Cloud excluded)

global-vision.title: Towards the eco-design of your service
global-vision.content:
This graph represents the various environmental impacts attributed to your digital service for 1 year of operation. It takes into account the entire lifecycle of the equipments that enables your service to operate (from manufacturing to end of life) for all the criteria listed on the left side of the screen.

​It helps you understand where to start your analysis in order to effectively reduce the impact of your service. But beware: by seeking to reduce the impact of one criterion, you run the risk of transferring the impact to another criterion or another phase of the life cycle (eco-design principles). One way of avoiding this pitfall is to demonstrate sobriety at all levels of your service.

​ A scale suited to multi-criteria analysis: the people equivalent.

​ All graphs are expressed in 'people Eq': to understand this unit, imagine defining a fixed amount for each resident of the planet, corresponding to the planetary limits that must not be exceeded individually to guarantee the overall balance of the system. This theoretical fixed amount is obtained by dividing the maximum quantity of negative externalities allowed by the Earth system (as defined in this technical report about consumption and consumer footprint) by the number of people.

​This unit makes it possible to compare the criteria and target your eco-design action plan (see eco-design definition) on what really matters.

​ To find out more about what's at stake: check this report on the environmental impact of ICT.

​ To carry out an audit of your application, the Référentiel Général d'Ecoconception de Services Numériques (RGESN) is a great starting point.

terminal.title: Analysis and ecoconception leverage
terminal.content:
Here you are looking at the impact of the terminals using your digital service.​

The calculation method currently used as the reference in LCA methods takes into account the type of equipment used, its location, and user journey times. ​

The type of equipment on which the service is consumed has an influence on the impact at the manufacturing, distribution, and end-of-life stages: the larger and more complex the equipment, the greater its impact. To reduce the impact, you can make sure that your service runs on terminals with small screens, on older equipment (OS more than 5 years old, etc.) and with low performance; you will then be helping to reduce the renewal of equipment... and the digital divide. ​

The location of users influences the impact of the service. It is directly linked to the methods used to produce the electrical energy consumed when the service is in use.​

Finally, you can optimise the user experience by eliminating functions that provide little or no value, which will also reduce the infrastructure required.

network.title: Analysis and ecoconception leverage
network.content:
This graph shows the impact of data exchanged on the network.​

This impact is proportional to the quantity of GB exchanged on the mobile network, and for the fixed network, the impact mainly depends on the size of the network (optical fiber or copper cables).​

It is generally preferable to use a fixed network, which has less impact than the mobile network if you reduce the impact to the number of GB exchanged (see this study on digital technologies in Europe and this survey on sustainable digital). ​

To reduce this impact, reduce the amount of data exchanged as much as possible by:​

- Questioning the need (is the presence of a video necessary? Can text replace an image? Is HD essential?) ​

- Optimizing formats (image size and compression) ​

- Respecting best practice about volumetry (not automatically launching videos, avoiding infinite page scrolling, using standard fonts, etc.)

server.title: Analysis and ecoconception leverage
server.content:
Here is a breakdown of the impact of hosting your service. This graph enables you to identify the servers on which you need to focus your attention. ​

To reduce the impact of servers, your levers for action relate to: ​

- The physical equipment used: replace the dedicated server with one of the VMs to combine resources, adjust the characteristics of the server as closely as possible to your needs, such as its computing power, RAM and storage capacity, etc. ​

- The way you use them: shutdown outside usage periods, autoscaling, load rate (even if not yet taken into account in the calculation), data retention time, use of caches, etc. ​

- The way it is maintained by the infrastructure teams: lifespan of equipment, pooling of resources, datacenter efficiency, etc. ​

You can click on the graph to identify the action levers you can take on your servers

server-lifecycle.title: Analysis and ecoconception leverage
server-lifecycle.content:
Here is the distribution of your server impact according to its lifecycle step. ​

In order to reduce the use's impact, you need to reduce the amount of energy consumed by your server or VM. To do so, you can transfer to a more efficient datacenter (it means, with a lower PUE and in a country with a less impacting electric mix – see table on the impact of electricity mixes).​ ​

For a compute server, the aim is to reduce the calculation's quantity (by selecting less greedy technologies, by deleting functionalities, by optimizing treatments … see good practices in digital service ecodesign for software developers).​ ​

For a storage server, the aim is to especially reduce the reading/writing operations and optimize the fill rates to limit the number of servers required. ​​

For other impacts, the levers depends on the servers, their lifespan, their mutualization type and level.

cloudservice.title: Analysis and ecoconception leverage
cloudservice.content:
Here's a breakdown of the impact of hosting your service in the cloud. This chart will help you identify the instances you need to focus on.

Please note: unlike on-premises servers, cloud service providers provide little information about the physical resources allocated. We therefore use a calculation method that is not used by cloud providers.

To reduce the impact of cloud instances, your levers of action relate to :

-How you use them: shutdowns outside windows of use, autoscaling, load rate (even if not yet included in the calculation), data retention time, use of caches, etc.

-The location of your instances: choose a hosting provider whose servers are located in a country with low power consumption. Wherever possible, it's also a good idea to choose a host that's close to your users or identified activities.

You can also follow the sustainability best practice guides specific to each public cloud provider:
- Azure best practice guide
- GCP best practice guide
- AWS best practice guide

You can click on the graphic to specify the levers you can mobilise on your servers.

cloud-lifecycle.title: Analysis and ecoconception leverage
cloud-lifecycle.content:
Here is the distribution of your instance type impact according to its lifecycle step. ​

In order to reduce the use's impact, you need to reduce the amount of energy consumed. To do so, you can transfer to a more efficient datacenter (it means, with a lower PUE and in a country with a less impacting electric mix – see table on the impact of electricity mixes).

For a compute server, the aim is to reduce the calculation's quantity (by selecting less greedy technologies, by deleting functionalities, by optimizing treatments … see more).​

For a storage server, the aim is to especially reduce the reading/writing operations and optimize the fill rates to limit the number of servers required.

For other impacts, the levers depends on the servers, their lifespan, their mutualization type and level.

global-vision.description:
This graph represents the various environmental impacts attributed to your digital service for one year of operation. It takes into account the entire life cycle of the equipment that enables your service to function (its manufacturing, distribution, use, and end of life), for all the criteria selected during the calculation.
In this case, the criteria are {{criteria}}.
global-vision.scale:
All the tool's graphs are expressed in "people Equivalent". To understand this unit, imagine that an equal allowance is defined for each inhabitant of the planet, corresponding to the planetary boundaries that should not be individually exceeded to ensure the global system's balance. This theoretical allowance is obtained by dividing the maximum amount of negative externalities tolerated by the Earth system (as defined in this technical report about consumption and consumer footprint) by the number of people.
This unit allows for comparing the criteria with each other and targeting your eco-design action plan (see eco-design definition) on what truly matters, avoiding impact transfers.
global-vision.text-description: In descending order, the impact is found on:
global-vision.text-description-iterate: {{impactName}} axis with {{impactValue}} people equivalent ({{rawValue}} {{unit}}) with {{resource}} representing {{resourceValue}} people equivalent ({{resourceRawValue}} {{resourceUnit}})
global-vision.analysis: This graph helps you determine where to begin your analysis to effectively reduce the impacts of your service. However, be cautious—by trying to reduce the impact of one criterion, you may inadvertently shift impacts to another criterion or another phase of the life cycle (eco-design principles). One way to avoid this pitfall is to practice sobriety at all levels of your service.
global-vision.to-go-further:
Better understand the issues: check this report on the environmental impact of ICT.
Conduct an audit of your application: the General Repository for the Eco-design of Digital Services (RGESN) is a very good starting point.

criteria.description: This graph shows the distribution of impacts for your digital service and is your starting point for taking concrete action: depending on the third party observed, the actions you can take will differ.
criteria.text-description: In descending order for {{resource}} criteria, the three most significant impacts are:
criteria.analysis: Bibliographic studies (report on the environmental impact of ICT + brief on digital technology's environmental footprint) often show that the most significant impact of a digital service is that linked to user terminals, followed by servers and finally networks.
criteria.to-go-further: Click on the graph to analyze more precisely where your service's impacts come from. You will find some levers for action in these inserts, and to go further, here are some relevant references: RGESN, 115 Web Ecodesign Best Practices, Designers Ethiques, EcoInfo, GreenIT Analysis.

terminal-type.description: This graph shows the distribution of the impact of devices using your digital service according to their type.
terminal-type.text-description: The types of devices that have the greatest impact on service usage, in descending order, are:
terminal-type.analysis: The type of equipment on which the service is consumed has an impact on manufacturing, distribution, and end-of-life disposal: the larger and more complex the equipment, the greater its impact. To reduce the impact, you can ensure that your service runs on terminals with small screens, on older equipment (OS older than 5 years, etc.) and low-performance devices; you will then contribute to reducing equipment renewal...and the digital divide. ​
terminal-type.to-go-further: Click on the graph to analyze more precisely where your service's impacts come from. You will find some levers for action in these inserts, and to go further, here are some relevant references: RGESN, 115 Web Ecodesign Best Practices, Designers Ethiques, EcoInfo, GreenIT Analysis.

terminal-country.description:
This graph shows the impact of terminal use on your digital service based on their geographical location.
The location of users influences the impact of the service. It is directly linked to the method of production of the electrical energy consumed by the use of the service.
terminal-country.text-description: The countries most representative in terms of service usage, in descending order, are:
terminal-country.analysis: The data reveals significant differences between countries. This depends in particular on each country's own energy production.
terminal-country.to-go-further: The location of users influences the impact of the service. It is directly linked to the methods used to produce the electrical energy consumed when the service is in use.

terminal-lifecycle.description: This graph shows the repartition of the impact of your devices within their lifecycle (manufacturing, transportation, usage, end of life).
terminal-lifecycle.text-description: The lifecycle phases with the most impact in descending order are:
terminal-lifecycle.analysis:
The calculation method currently used as the reference in LCA methods takes into account the type of equipment used, its location, and user journey times. ​
The type of equipment on which the service is consumed has an influence on the impact at the manufacturing, distribution, and end-of-life stages: the larger and more complex the equipment, the greater its impact. To reduce the impact, you can make sure that your service runs on terminals with small screens, on older equipment (OS more than 5 years old, etc.) and with low performance; you will then be helping to reduce the renewal of equipment... and the digital divide.
terminal-lifecycle.to-go-further:
The location of users influences the impact of the service. It is directly linked to the methods used to produce the electrical energy consumed when the service is in use.​
You can optimise the user experience by eliminating functions that provide little or no value, which will also reduce the infrastructure required.

network.description: This graph shows the distribution of the impact of your digital services based on the networks used.
network.text-description: The networks with the greatest impact, in descending order, are:
network.analysis:
This graph shows the impact related to data exchanged on the network.
This impact is proportional to the amount of GB exchanged on the network for mobile devices and to the size of the network (fiber or copper) for fixed devices.
network.to-go-further:
It is generally preferable to use a fixed network, which has less impact than the mobile network if you reduce the impact to the number of GB exchanged (see this study on digital technologies in Europe and this survey on sustainable digital). ​

To reduce this impact, reduce the amount of data exchanged as much as possible by:​
- Questioning the need (is the presence of a video necessary? Can text replace an image? Is HD essential?) ​
- Optimizing formats (image size and compression) ​
- Respecting best practice about volumetry (not automatically launching videos, avoiding infinite page scrolling, using standard fonts, etc.)

server.description: This graph shows the distribution of the impact of the different instances of your Private Infrastructures.
server.text-description: The Private Infrastructures with the greatest impact on service usage, in descending order, are:
server.analysis: This graph allows you to detect Private Infrastructures that require your attention.
server.to-go-further:
To reduce the impact of servers, you can take action in the following areas:
- Physical equipment used: replace dedicated servers with VMs to pool resources, adjust server characteristics such as computing power, RAM, storage capacity, etc. as closely as possible to requirements.
- How you use them: shutting down outside of usage periods, autoscaling, load rates (even if not yet included in the calculation), data retention periods, use of caches, etc.
- How it is maintained by infrastructure teams: hardware lifespan, resource pooling, data center efficiency, etc.

server-lifecycle.description: This graph shows the distribution of your instance's impact based on its lifecycle.
server-lifecycle.text-description: The most impactful phases in the life cycle of your instance, in descending order, are:
server-lifecycle.analysis: This graph allows you to detect the impacts of your instance based on its lifecycle.
server-lifecycle.to-go-further:
To reduce the impact of use, you need to reduce the amount of energy consumed by your server or VM. To do this, you can migrate to a more efficient data center (i.e., one with a lower PUE and located in a country with a lower-impact electricity mix— see the table on the impact of electricity mixes).
For a computing server, this means reducing the amount of calculations performed (by selecting less energy-intensive technologies, removing features, optimizing processing, etc. – see best practices in eco-design of digital services for developers)).
For a storage server, the main objective is to reduce read/write operations and optimize fill rates to limit the number of servers required.
For other impacts, the levers depend on the servers, their lifespan, their level of sharing, and their type.

server-vm.description: This graph shows the distribution of the impact of your VM.
server-vm.text-description: In descending order, the VMs with the greatest impact are:
server-vm.text-description-iterate: - {{impactName}} with an impact of {{impactValue}} people equivalent ({{rawValue}} {{unit}})
server-vm.analysis: This graph allows you to detect the impact of your instance based on VMs.
server-vm.to-go-further:
To reduce the impact of use, you need to reduce the amount of energy consumed by your server or VM. To do this, you can migrate to a more efficient data center (i.e., one with a lower PUE and located in a country with a lower-impact electricity mix— see the table on the impact of electricity mixes).
For a computing server, this means reducing the amount of calculations performed (by selecting less energy-intensive technologies, removing features, optimizing processing, etc. – see best practices in eco-design of digital services for developers).
For a storage server, the main objective is to reduce read/write operations and optimize fill rates to limit the number of servers required.
For other impacts, the levers depend on the servers, their lifespan, their level of sharing, and their type.

cloudservice-location.description: This graph shows the distribution of the impact of your cloud services based on their location.
cloudservice-location.text-description: The locations with the greatest impact in descending order are:
cloudservice-location.analysis:
This graph shows the distribution of impacts related to your service's cloud hosting based on their location.

Please note: Unlike on-premise servers, cloud service providers reveal little information about the physical resources allocated. We therefore use a calculation method that is not the same as that used by cloud providers.
cloudservice-location.to-go-further:
To reduce the impact of cloud instances, you can take action in the following areas:
- How you use them: shutting them down when not in use, autoscaling, load rates (even if not yet included in the calculation), data retention periods, use of caches, etc.
- The location of your instances: choose a host whose servers are located in a country with low-impact electricity. Where possible, it is also a good idea to choose a host that is close to users or identified activities.
You can also follow the sustainability best practice guides specific to each public cloud provider:
- Azure best practice guide
- GCP best practice guide
- AWS best practice guide
You can click on the graph to specify the levers you can use on your servers.

cloudservice-instance.description: This graph shows the distribution of the impact of your various cloud instances.
cloudservice-instance.text-description: The cloud instances with the greatest impact in descending order are:
cloudservice-instance.analysis:
This graph shows the distribution of impacts related to your service's cloud hosting. This graph allows you to identify the instances on which you should focus your attention.

Please note: Unlike on-premise servers, cloud service providers reveal little information about the physical resources allocated. We therefore use a calculation method that differs from that used by cloud providers.
cloudservice-instance.to-go-further:
To reduce the impact of cloud instances, you can take action in the following areas:
- How you use them: shutting them down when not in use, autoscaling, load rates (even if not yet included in the calculation), data retention periods, use of caches, etc.
- The location of your instances: choose a host whose servers are located in a country with low-impact electricity. Where possible, it is also a good idea to choose a host that is close to users or identified activities.
You can also follow the sustainability best practice guides specific to each public cloud provider:
- Azure best practice guide
- GCP best practice guide
- AWS best practice guide
You can click on the graph to specify the levers you can use on your servers.

cloud-lifecycle.description: This graph shows the distribution of the impact of your cloud instances based on their lifecycle.
cloud-lifecycle.text-description: The stages of the life cycle of the cloud service {{cloudInstanceName}} with the greatest impact in descending order are:
cloud-lifecycle.analysis:
This graph shows the distribution of impacts related to your service's cloud hosting based on its lifecycle.

Please note: Unlike on-premise servers, cloud service providers reveal little information about the physical resources allocated. We therefore use a calculation method that is not the same as that used by cloud providers.
cloud-lifecycle.to-go-further:
To reduce the impact of use, you need to reduce the amount of energy consumed by your server or VM. To do this, you can migrate to a more efficient data center (i.e., one with a lower PUE and located in a country with a lower-impact electricity mix— see the table on the impact of electricity mixes).
For a computing server, this means reducing the amount of calculations performed (by selecting less energy-intensive technologies, removing features, optimizing processing, etc. – see best practices in eco-design of digital services for developers).
For a storage server, the main objective is to reduce read/write operations and optimize fill rates to limit the number of servers required.
For other impacts, the levers depend on the servers, their lifespan, their level of sharing, and their type.

climate-change.title: Climate change
climate-change.name: Climate change
climate-change.inventory-text: Global phenomenon of climate change characterized by a general increase in average temperatures, permanently modifying meteorological balances and ecosystems
climate-change.digital-services-card-title: Why Climate Change matters and how engage action ?
climate-change.digital-services-card-content:
Climate Change (kg CO2 eq.): this criteria measures radiative forcing as global warming potential (GWP100) that increase in the average global temperature resulting from greenhouse gas emission.

Bibliographic studies (report on the environmental impact of ICT + brief on digital technology's environmental footprint) often show that the most significant impact of a digital service is linked to the user terminals, followed by the servers and finally the networks.

This graph shows the distribution of impacts for your digital service, and is your entry point for concrete action: depending on the third party observed, the actions you can take will differ.

Click on the graph to analyze more precisely where the impacts of your service come from. In these inserts, you will find a number of levers for action, and here are a few relevant references to take you further: RGESN, 115 Web Ecodesign Best Practices, Designers Ethiques, EcoInfo, GreenIT Analysis.
climate-change.scale: Climate change (kg CO2 eq.): This criterion measures radiative forcing as global warming potential (GWP100), which increases the average global temperature resulting from greenhouse gas emissions.

resource-use.title: Resource use
resource-use.name: Resource use
resource-use.inventory-title: Depletion of natural resources (kg eq. Sb)
resource-use.inventory-text: Non-living resources naturally present in the environment. Among them, the rare earths, the increasing extraction of which causes the release of toxic pollutants, are in limited quantities.
resource-use.digital-services-card-title: Why Resource Use matters and how engage action ?
resource-use.digital-services-card-content:
Resource Use (kg Sb eq.): this criteria measures abiotic resource depletion relative to ultimate reserve. Abiotic resource correspond to all raw materials that are not derived from living organisms, which are non-renewable. Their depletion depriving for future generations.

Bibliographic studies (report on the environmental impact of ICT + brief on digital technology's environmental footprint) often show that the most significant impact of a digital service is linked to the user terminals, followed by the servers and finally the networks.

This graph shows the distribution of impacts for your digital service, and is your entry point for concrete action: depending on the third party observed, the actions you can take will differ.

Click on the graph to analyze more precisely where the impacts of your service come from. resource-use.scale: Resource Use (kg Sb eq.): this criteria measures abiotic resource depletion relative to ultimate reserve. Abiotic resource correspond to all raw materials that are not derived from living organisms, which are non-renewable. Their depletion depriving for future generations.

ionising-radiation.title: Ionising radiation
ionising-radiation.name: Ionising radiation
ionising-radiation.inventory-text: Radiation that produces ionizations in the material it passes through. Even in low doses, it can lead to risks of long-term effects like cancer.
ionising-radiation.digital-services-card-title: Why Ionizing Radiation matters and how engage action ?
ionising-radiation.digital-services-card-content:
Ionizing Radiation (kBq U235 eq.): this criteria measures Human exposure efficiency relative to Uranium 235, that produces ionizations in the material it passes through. Even in low doses, it can lead to risks of long-term effects like cancer.

acidification.title: Acidification
acidification.name: Acidification
acidification.inventory-text: Emission of sulfur compounds (mainly due to combustion processes in the production of electricity, heating and transport) generates a global acidification of the oceans, atmosphere and soils which disturbs the ecosystems.
acidification.digital-services-card-title: Why Acidification matters and how engage action ?
acidification.digital-services-card-content:
Acidification (mol H+ eq.): this criteria measures accumulated exceedance of H+ ions produce by emission of sulfur compounds (mainly due to combustion processes in the production of electricity, heating and transport) generates a global acidification of the oceans, atmosphere and soils which disturbs the ecosystems.

Bibliographic studies (report on the environmental impact of ICT + brief on digital technology's environmental footprint) often show that the most significant impact of a digital service is linked to the user terminals, followed by the servers and finally the networks.

particulate-matter.title: Particulate matter
particulate-matter.name: Particulate matter
particulate-matter.inventory-text: Microscopic particles suspended in the ambient air. They are fine enough to enter the respiratory tract causing a harmful effect on health.
particulate-matter.digital-services-card-title: Why Particulate Matter matters and how engage action ?
particulate-matter.digital-services-card-content:
Particulate Matter (Disease incidence): this criteria measures impact on human health (disease incidence) caused by Microscopic particles suspended in the ambient air (fine enough to enter the respiratory tract causing a harmful effect on health) and its precursors (e.g. sulfur and nitrogen oxides).

Bibliographic studies (report on the environmental impact of ICT + brief on digital technology's environmental footprint) often show that the most significant impact of a digital service is linked to the user terminals, followed by the servers and finally the networks.

ozone-depletion.title: Ozone depletion
ozone-depletion.name: Ozone depletion
ozone-depletion.inventory-text: Depletion of the stratospheric ozone layer protecting from hazardous ultraviolet radiation.
ozone-depletion.digital-services-card-title: Why Ozone Depletion matters and how to engage action ?
ozone-depletion.digital-services-card-content:
Ozone depletion (kg CFC-11 eq.) : this criteria measures the depletion of the stratospheric ozone layer protecting from hazardous ultraviolet radiation.

photochemical-ozone-formation.title: Photochemical ozone formation
photochemical-ozone-formation.name: Photochemical ozone formation
photochemical-ozone-formation.inventory-text: Potential of harmful tropospheric ozone formation ('summer smog') from air emissions.
photochemical-ozone-formation.digital-services-card-title: Why Photochemical ozone formation matters and how to engage action ?
photochemical-ozone-formation.digital-services-card-content:

eutrophication-terrestrial.title: Eutrophication, terrestrial
eutrophication-terrestrial.name: Eutrophication, terrestrial
eutrophication-terrestrial.inventory-text: Eutrophication and potential impact on ecosystems caused by nitrogen and phosphorous emissions mainly due to fertilizers, combustion, sewage systems.

eutrophication-terrestrial.digital-services-card-content:

declarations.title: G4IT Declarations
declarations.commited-paragraph: G4IT Team is committed to an eco-design approach aimed at reducing the environmental footprint of its digital services. This declaration was drafted on 28/04/2025 as part of the implementation of the General Policy Framework for the Ecodesign of Digital Services (2024 version).
declarations.framework-paragraph: This framework, developed jointly by Arcep and Arcom in collaboration with ADEME, DINUM, CNIL, and Inria, outlines the key directions for integrating digital sobriety into the design and operation of digital services. The official document is available on the Arcep website:
declarations.framework-link: General Policy Framework for the Ecodesign of Digital Services – 2024 version
declarations.objectives-paragraph: Its implementation is based on four main objectives:
declarations.functional-areas-paragraph: This declaration aims to be exhaustive regarding the use cases covered by the application, represented by three main functional areas:
declarations.first-objectives: Design more sustainable digital services to extend the lifespan of user devices;
declarations.second-objectives: Promote a mindset of digital sobriety in response to attention-grabbing strategies, consistent with international environmental commitments;
declarations.third-objectives: Reduce IT resources used throughout the digital services’ lifecycle, particularly through data traffic and infrastructure optimization;
declarations.fourth-objectives: Enhance transparency regarding the environmental footprint of digital services.
declarations.functional-areas-first: Impact assessment of an inventory, which may correspond to an information system, an application portfolio, or a set of physical and virtual equipment;
declarations.functional-areas-second: Impact assessment of a digital service;
declarations.functional-areas-third: Administration of organizations and platform users.

key-results.title: Key Results
key-results.key-results-paragraph: The compliance audit assessed the RGESN (2024 version) compliance of the website at {{ecoDesignPercent}}% as of 28/04/2025.

action-item.title: Additionally, the following action items will be implemented in 2025:

item.one: Improve display with 200% zoom to enable use on different types of screens;
item.two: Conduct a POC on native compilation with Springboot 3.3 to reduce RAM and CPU consumption;
item.three: Migrate the integration environment to a data center in France and move hosting to a more committed, sovereign, and transparent cloud provider.

declarations.future-development: To achieve this, reviews and audits will be conducted annually, and eco-design considerations are integrated into daily feature development.
declarations.accessibility-declaration-para: G4IT Team is committed to making its websites, intranets, extranets, and software accessible, in accordance with Article 47 of Law No. 2005-102 of February 11, 2005.
declarations.declaration-applies: This accessibility declaration applies to the website
declarations.compliance-status-para: The website is not compliant with the General Accessibility Improvement Framework (RGAA), version 4. Non-compliance is due to the points and exemptions listed below.

test-result.title: Test Results
test-result.one: 45.31% of RGAA version 4 criteria are met

feedback-contact.title: Feedback and Contact
feedback-contact.para: If you are unable to access content or a service, you can contact the G4IT representative to obtain an accessible alternative or content in another form.
feedback-contact.contact-entity: Contact the responsible entity for the online service

appeal-procedures.title: Appeal Procedures
appeal-procedures.para: If you notice an accessibility issue and do not receive a satisfactory response, you can:
appeal-procedures.one: Write to the Defender of Rights:
appeal-procedures.two: Contact the regional delegate of the Defender of Rights:
appeal-procedures.three: Send a postage-free letter to: Défenseur des droits, Libre réponse 71120, 75342 Paris CEDEX 07, France

accessibility.declaration-pdf: Download the full eco-design statement as a pdf ({{pdfSize}}KB)
accessibility.external-link: Open the page {{title}} in a new tab

multi-year-accessibility-plan.title: Multi-year Accessibility Plan
multi-year-accessibility-plan.para: In alignment with the RGAA and our continuous improvement approach, we are committed to enhancing the accessibility of our digital services. Our action plan is structured around the following timelines:

training.title: Training Plan:
training.para: All members of the G4IT team (excluding occasional contributors) must have completed an e-learning awareness module on accessible website development during the first month of their assignment.

checklist.title: Accessibility Checklist:
checklist.para: Implementation of a checklist in the Definition of Done (DoD) for all US front-end developments to verify key accessibility best practices.

monitoring.title: Accessibility Monitoring:
monitoring.para: Monitoring of each CYPRESS scenario release and correction of critical and serious anomalies before the production release (MEP).

zoom.title: Zoom 200%:
zoom.para: Allow users to zoom in at 200% without loss of content or functionality on the two main user journeys:

is-module.title: Inventory Module:
is-module.para: Visualisation of the impact of physical equipment.

ds-module.title: Digital Service Module:
ds-module.para: Visualisation of the impact of a digital service.

training-plan.title: Training Plan:
training-plan.para: Product Owners of the G4IT team must have completed training on accessible website design within the first 3 months of their assignment.

graph.title: Graph Accessibility:
graph.para: Implementation of textual descriptions summarising the main information presented in the multi-criteria radar charts.

audit.title: Accessibility Audit:
audit.para: Carrying out a new accessibility audit in 2026.

training-plan.title: Training Plan:
training-plan.para: All G4IT team members must have completed accessibility training tailored to their roles (Product Owner, front-end developer, tester, etc.) within the first 3 months of their assignment.
